content.heading: HTML Attributes
paragraphs:
All HTML elements can have attributes.

Attributes provide additional information about elements.

Attributes are always specified in the start tag.

Attributes usually come in name/value pairs like: name="value".

content.heading: The src Attribute
paragraphs: The tag is used to embed an image in an HTML page. The src attribute specifies the path to the image to be displayed.

content.heading: The width and height Attributes
paragraphs: The tag should also contain the width and height attributes, which specify the width and height of the image (in pixels).

content.heading: The alt Attribute
paragraphs: The required alt attribute for the tag specifies an alternate text for an image, if the image cannot be displayed. This can be due to a slow connection or an error in the src attribute.

content.heading: Example
The style Attribute
paragraphs: The style attribute is used to add styles to an element, such as color, font, size, and more.

content.heading: The lang Attribute
paragraphs: You should always include the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, to declare the language of the Web page.

content.heading: The title Attribute
paragraphs: The title attribute defines some extra information about an element.

content.heading: We Suggest: Always Use Lowercase Attributes
paragraphs: The HTML standard does not require lowercase attribute names. However, it is recommended to use lowercase attributes in HTML.

content.heading: We Suggest: Always Quote Attribute Values
paragraphs: The HTML standard does not require quotes around attribute values. However, it is recommended to use quotes in HTML.

content.heading: Single or Double Quotes?
paragraphs: Double quotes around attribute values are the most common in HTML, but single quotes can also be used.
